phuṭhā.meaning_2: to burst; to split; to crack
phuṭhā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form 'phuṭhā' appears to be a non-standard or dialectal variant of the 3rd singular present indicative 'phuṭati', possibly influenced by regional pronunciation or scribal error. No contextual sentences are provided, so the meaning is based on standard Pāḷi usage.

meghissa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Meghissa is the genitive singular form of megha, a masculine noun meaning 'cloud'. Without contextual sentences, the usage is interpreted as a standard possessive genitive.

bhāvitaṭṭhaṅgiko.meaning_2: cultivated in the eightfold path; developed in the eight limbs
bhāvitaṭṭhaṅgiko.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective describing something or someone who has cultivated or developed the eightfold path (ariya aṭṭhaṅgika magga) in Pāli Buddhism, referring to spiritual development.

punarāgahe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form punarāgahe is locative singular of the compound punarāga, meaning 'in renewed attachment' or 'in returning to passion'. It combines the adverb puna 'again' with rāga 'attachment, passion', indicating a relapse into desire. Without provided sentences, the contextual usage is inferred from the compound structure common in Pāli texts discussing spiritual obstacles.

vanamogāhissasi.meaning_2: you will plunge into the forest; you will get immersed in the woods
vanamogāhissasi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a periphrastic future form constructed from the object 'vanam' (acc. sg. of vana, 'forest'), the prefixed verb ogāhati ('to plunge into'), with the future suffix issa- and 2nd person singular ending -si. The meaning implies a future action of immersing oneself deeply into the forest, possibly metaphorical for entering or indulging in it.

upaṭṭhahituṃ.meaning_2: to stand by; to attend upon; to serve; to be present
upaṭṭhahituṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Infinitive form upaṭṭhahituṃ indicates purpose, often used in contexts of attending to duties or serving a superior in Vinaya texts.

āpucchahaṃnāpucchahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form āpucchahaṃnāpucchahaṃ appears to be a scribal error or dittography for āpucchahaṃ, a 1st person singular aorist of āpucchati, meaning 'I asked permission'. The repeated nāpucchahaṃ may be an erroneous insertion of the negative form, but the primary lemma is the affirmative.

nāpucchahaṃ.meaning_2: having not asked; having not enquired; having not questioned
nāpucchahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form nāpucchahaṃ is an irregular absolutive combining the negative prefix na (contracted to nā before a-vowel) with the root √pucch 'to ask', and suffixed with -haṃ, a variant of -aṃ used in some contexts for emphasis or stylistic reasons in Pāli texts.

paṭiccharati.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word appears to be a present tense verb form, likely the 3rd person singular, based on the dictionary entries provided. No specific contextual sentence is given, so the general meanings from the entries are used.

pontiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form pontiṃ appears to be an accusative singular of ponnaṃ, a contracted variant of puṇṇa common in some Pāḷi texts. It likely functions as the direct object in the sentence, referring to an act of merit.

vodhuna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Vodhuna is an indeclinable adverb derived from the root √vudh (to grow, increase) with the suffix -una, used to introduce a contrast or exception in the sentence.

āhārisaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form āhārisaṃ appears to be an accusative singular of a tatpuruṣa compound 'āhārisa', where āhāra (food) qualifies arisa (piles or haemorrhoids), indicating a condition caused by or related to eating. No sentences provided for further contextual analysis.

chuṭṭho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Ordinal numeral adjective derived from the cardinal catuttha; used to denote the fourth in a sequence or position.

chuṭṭhūna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular neuter of the ordinal numeral 'chuṭṭha', used to denote the fourth instance or case in a sequence, common in Vinaya contexts for classifying rules or offenses.

pidhitvā.meaning_2: having covered; having closed; having concealed
pidhitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form pidhitvā appears to be a variant or scribal error for pidhāya, a common absolutive in Pāḷi texts. Used to indicate a completed action prior to the main verb, often in contexts of covering or protecting something.

yācitassā.meaning_2: asked for; begged for; pleaded for
yācitassā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form yācitassā appears to be a scribal error or variant for yācitā + tassā (feminine dative singular of the past participle), meaning 'having been asked for her' or 'begged for her hand'; likely in a context of requesting marriage or a favor from a female.

anukkamaṇikagaṇanāvasena.meaning_2: according to the sequential counting; by means of the numbering in order
anukkamaṇikagaṇanāvasena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental adverbial compound formed from 'anukkamaṇikā' (table of contents or sequence), 'gaṇanā' (counting or numbering), and 'vasena' (by means of). It likely refers to a method of sequential enumeration or indexing, possibly in a catalog or list context.
